Complaining that this movie is different than the 70 year old one is like complaining that the Dark Knight is bad because it is not like the 60's Batman TV show. Apples and oranges - two different audiences.

This is in no way a remake.  It is a direct sequel in a long line of books fourteen by the original author and a few more after that by various authors.

It is indeed a lot more true to the books than the first movie.  Take a look at this picture (from the original book) and you will see for yourself.
http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cb/Cowardly_lion2.jpg
Sorry j-man, maybe it's a bad movie but at least I know how to spell awful.
I've always hated "The Wizard of Oz" but "Return to Oz" was always one of my childhood favorites. J-Man246 is an idiot.

I know this is a bit old now, but just to clarify a point - This is not a remake of The Wizard of OZ - It is based on another book by Lyman Frank Baum called "Ozma of OZ". It is quite faithful to the original text (probably more so than The Wizard of OZ is to the original book by Baum "The Wonderful Wizard of OZ". So it's not a sequel, it's a completely different film based mainly on another book in the series of 16 about OZ. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozma_of_Oz#Film.2C_TV_or_theatrical_adaptations

does anyone know where I can get a subtitle in English for this version of the movie, I can't seem to find one anywhere that matches it. I found a few on opensubs, and allsubs, but they are awful. I also tried to match with subtitles workshop but I have to edit all the subs because they are full of spelling errors, and unnecessary spaces, characters, etc....

I'm sorry, but for a live-action disney movie, this film is actually pretty good. Dealing with profound loss, insurmountable odds, and stick-to-it-iveness without the sickly sweet sappy corn filler.  It's deliciously dark at times and downright laughable at others, but you really do feel yourself compelled by a sense of wonder and i daresay hope for our heroine.

not that i'm a snarky film critic, and i just ran across this film, not actively looking... but i do recall it as one of the films i enjoyed as a child thinking 'this is what film could be'
